Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I stared at the clock on my monitor, watching the minutes slip away. As an engineer, I was responsible for ensuring our new product met the latest safety standard, which had just been updated last week. The release was tomorrow, and I still needed to finalize the documentation to prove our compliance. My manager had made it clear: no shortcuts, no delays—regulatory evidence was non-negotiable.

But today was also election day. I’d promised myself I’d vote, and the polling station was only a short drive away. The polls were open all day, and my schedule was unusually light, but every time I considered stepping away, another email pinged in—questions from the compliance team, last-minute requests for clarification. I felt the weight of my responsibility to my team and the company, but also the civic duty tugging at me. I kept glancing at the time, torn between the expectation to deliver flawless, timely work and the obligation to participate in the democratic process. My stomach twisted as I tried to decide which role I could afford to let down, even for just an hour.
